references: Settings. Since the proposed CSS is a model-agnostic training scheme, which can be seamlessly incorporated into different VQA architectures. To evaluate the effectiveness of CSS to boost the debiasing performance of different backbones, we incorporated the CSS into multiple architectures including: UpDnÂ [4], PoE (Product of Experts)Â [14, 27], RUBiÂ [10], LMHÂ [14]. Especially, PoE, RUBi, LMH are ensemble-based methods. All results are shown in TableÂ 1.

references: Results. The results are reported in TableÂ 3. When trained and tested on the VQA-CP v2 dataset (i.e., left side of TableÂ 3), the LMH-CSS achieves a new state-of-the-art performance over all question categories. Particularly, CSS improves the performance of LMH with a 6.50% absolution performance gains (58.95% vs. 52.45%). When trained and tested on the VQA v2 dataset (i.e., middle side of TableÂ 3), the CSS results in a minor drop in the performance by 1.74% for LMH. For completeness, we further compared the performance drop between the two benchmarks. Different from previous models that suffer severe performance drops (e.g., 23.74% in UpDn, and 9.19% in LMH), the LMH-CSS can significantly decrease the performance drop into 0.96%, which demonstrate that the effectiveness of CSS to further reduce the language biases in VQA.

references: Settings. We equipped the existing state-of-the-art visual-explainable model SCRÂ [39] into the LMH framework, and compared it with CSS. Results are reported in TableÂ 4 (a).

Settings. We evaluate the effectiveness of CSS to improve the visual-explainable ability on both quantitative and qualitative results. For quantitative results, since we lack human annotations about the critical objects for each question, we regard the ğ’®â€‹â„â€‹â„³ğ’®â„â„³\mathcal{SIM} score (SectionÂ 3.2.1 IO_Sel) as pseudo ground truth. Thus, we design a new metric Average Importance (ğ’œâ€‹â„ğ’œâ„\mathcal{AI}): the average ğ’®â€‹â„â€‹â„³ğ’®â„â„³\mathcal{SIM} score of the top-K objects with highest |sâ€‹(a,ğ’—)|ğ‘ ğ‘ğ’—|s(a,\bm{v})|. The results are shown in TableÂ 4 (b). For qualitative results, we illustrated in FigureÂ 5 (a).

Results. From TableÂ 4 (b), we can observe that CSS dramatically improves the ğ’œâ€‹â„ğ’œâ„\mathcal{AI} scores, which means the actually influential objects are more related to the QA pair. From FigureÂ 5 (a), we can find that the CSS helps the model to make predictions based on critical objects (i.e., green boxes), and suppress the influence of irrelevant objects (i.e., red boxes).

Settings. As discussed in previous workÂ [37], being robust to diverse rephrasing of questions is one of key behaviors of a question-sensitive model. To more accurately evaluate the robustness, we re-splited the existing dataset VQA-RephrasingsÂ [37] with the same splits as VQA-CP, and denoted it as VQA-CP-Rephrasings. For evaluation, we used the standard metric Consensus Score Câ€‹Sâ€‹(k)ğ¶ğ‘†ğ‘˜CS(k). Results are reported in TableÂ 4 (c) (left). We refer readers toÂ [37] for more details about the VQA-Rephrasings and metric Câ€‹Sâ€‹(k)ğ¶ğ‘†ğ‘˜CS(k).

Results. From TableÂ 4 (c), we can observe that Q-CSS dramatically improves the robustness to diverse rephrasings of questions. Furthermore, V-CSS can help to further improve the robustness, i.e., ğ’â€‹ğ’®â€‹ğ’®ğ’ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{CSS} achieves the best performance.

where a^^ğ‘\hat{a} is the model predicted answer for sample (I,Q)ğ¼ğ‘„(I,Q), ğŸ1\mathbf{1} is an indicator function. The results are reported in TableÂ 4 (c). For qualitative results, we illustrated in FigureÂ 5 (b).

Results. From TableÂ 4 (c), we can observe that CSS helps the model to benefit more from the critical words, i.e., removing critical words results in more confidence drops for the ground-truth answers. From FigureÂ 5 (b), we can find that CSS helps the model to make predictions based on critical words (e.g., â€œstoveâ€ or â€œlasagnaâ€), i.e., forcing model to understand the whole questions before making predictions.
